content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a risk-taker, I would choose strategy R, as I believe that the potential for a higher reward outweighs the risk of a lower payoff in some rounds. However, it's essential to consider the behavior of the anonymous player. If they are also a risk-taker like me, we might end up with more R choices and thus earn 45$ per round more frequently. But if they are conservative (choosing B), I might have to adapt my strategy accordingly to maximize my earnings. In any case, I would expect that after several rounds, the payoffs would even out due to the game's structure. So, I choose R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both of us chose R in the previous round, so we both earned 45$. Now, as a risk-taker, I would consider deviating from my initial strategy to maximize potential gains. If my opponent sticks to their strategy and chooses R again, I will still earn 45$ (assuming they do the same). However, if my opponent changes their strategy and chooses B, I would gain 40$, as opposed to the 20$ I would have earned had I stuck with R. Therefore, in this specific situation, I would choose B for the next round{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I chose B, and my opponent chose R in the previous round, so I received a payoff of 40$, while my opponent got 0$. Now, as a risk-taker, I would consider the possibility that my opponent might change their strategy due to the outcome of the previous round. If they stick with R, I would still gain 40$ in this round (assuming they do the same). However, if they adapt and choose B this time, I would earn 20$, as opposed to the 45$ I could have earned had I chosen R instead. Considering these factors, I would again deviate from my initial strategy and choose R for the next round{R}.
